In the interest of accuracy: life began in the oceans, but there was a pretty diverse ecosystem on land before our ancestors joined the trend. Arthropods, nematodes, mollusks, tardigrades, etc. all figured out life in the air (some of them multiple times in different lineages) well before fish, not to mention all the non-animal life.

6:41 Actually, epiglottis' downward turn alone cannot ensure the full closure of the windpipe. What's necessarily more is the ELEVATION of the tube-like pharyngeal muscles, bringing upward the trachea and the esophagus, so that the opening to the windpipe is squeezed and securely closed.

*Trust me. I went to med school.*

Most, say a half, of the cartoon illustration of swallowing just neglects this part. I was very surprised when taught about this.

(keywords: pharyngeal phase of swallowing, videofluofoscopic swallow study)

In describing bulk flow, you didn't mention one of the main forces that leads to shrinking of the lungs and positive intrapulmonary pressure for exhaling: the elasticity of the lungs and their alveoli. The tendency of the lung tissue to snap back down to a smaller size by default has implications for energy consumption while breathing. It also is key in understanding COPD, collapsed lung (atelectasis), and emphysema, among other conditions. Maybe we'll hit that and lung surfactant next time?
